												Old school Karate action done right in the 2D world drawing on influences of some of the most challenging competition games ever made from Karate Champ to Street Fighter.  No crazy complex combos, the simple controls allow for strategic planning of your moves precisely when used in this competitive fighter.  Many games people buy because their cheap then never play one hour of them, this game is to awesome to not play.   This game does the hardest thing in gaming, taking a simple concept and making it fun to play with working controls.  The competition style of the game uses a variety of moves that force the player NOT to just mash the buttons but plan each move to become a black belt master of their own.  The game is riddled with spelling errors and sentences that make no sense, but all that anyone needs to understand is "Karate is life!!!!"  At first many will think the strange phrasing of sentences is some kind of retro feel, though after checking their website, it seems to just be the way they write in general for whatever reason.   Either way it is awesome and fits the game perfectly.  This game has the most important aspect working flawlessly, the ai opponents are challenging and its never the same fight twice.  The music in the game is just as hardcore as the visuals.  Sick of boring drawn out realistic hipster type games from the last few years?  If so then karate Master 2 is your cure!   As the game says, get ready to "get covered in glory."  How often does anyone get to say that?  Imagine someone asking you how your day is, now finally you can reply saying you are covered in glory. What a good day to be you!Rating:  10/10  Value:  $9.99 *for those who want the awesomesauce of Karate Master 1, its free from the developer and can be downloaded on their official website:  http://www.criansoft.com/eng/Karate%20Master%20KDB.html

												I am really digging this game.It kinda has an SNK fighting game feel to it, but there is a skill progression that really adds depth and playthrough time to the game.  As you progress further in your stats, you unlock new training minigames that really help keep them from feeling stale.As for the controls, they're pretty tight for being an indie title. Personally, I'm using a USB-connected SNES controller and it works beautifully with this game.The graphics really capture the feel of the transitional period between the 16-bit and 32-bit console eras (think NEO-GEO), and they are of much higher quality than your average indie fare.The sound effects and music really make this game shine, once again perfectly capturing that bygone era that a lot of us spent middle school listening to as we played our games.If I were to criticize anything, it would probably be the rough translation job, but it's a minor slight that doesn't take away from the game much at all.The devs have some real talent, and this game is well worth the $10. 												Nineteen eighty five called, it would like to have a word with you about cheesy Karate games. Specifically, I would like you to cast your mind back to the spectrum era. Long loading times, terribad graphics, but a blank canvas where game creativity was about pushing boundaries and exploring what games could be. One of those many explorations was a title called IK+ (International Karate +), a glorious bit of code involving some pixellated men in pyjamas whacking each other in the goal of changing their belt colours. The controls were tight, the fighting was good, and the feeling was very much that of a cheesy b-movie. Hell, the Amiga version had Stephen Segal (or a very good likeness)[www.atarimania.com] on the cover along with what looks to be Chuck Norris delivering a trademark kick to some poor sod. Fighting games have wavered in and out of vogue, travelling between the more realistic and the more fantastical over the generations, but the pure, basic Karate game sortof vanished into the ether...... UNTIL NOW...... KAHATAE MASTAH. NOCKA DOON BALOO. OSU!It's gloriously throwback, the graphics are retro Amiga era, the script has more chinglish than a motherboard manual, you get to Karate Fight a bull and a bear (yes, you get the opportunity to punch a bear), and you get to do a jump kick over a car to promote your dojo. It's that kind of finely matured cheese. Jackie Chan would be -proud- to feature in such a script. It has so much terribleness (like the fact you can exit without saving very easily and the game does a TERRIBLE job of warning you) that it has no right to be as good as it is. Yet, it is. It's good, it's good in the way finely matured cheese is good.The game features a mix of tournaments, one shot fights against various opponents (who if you beat, will then appear in the said same tournaments), special encounters such as the aforementioned "DO A FLYING KICK OVER A CAR!", and occasional expositions of horribly written story, with english so badly written even google translate looks at me and throws it's arms up in despair. You can read it, and you'll laugh, it's that wonderfully bad. In between the fighting and the b-reel script you get to train your fighter in a fantastically diverse set of mini-games (some are genius, others... not so much), and there's a limited RPG style progression system where you'll tinker with the stats of your fighter, and can even suffer injuries and get to participate in a mini game where you have to recover from those (and the first time that happens, you get some cringeworthy story for that too).The fighting however is -good-, really good, it uses the tekken style approach of mapping left and right legs and arms to seperate buttons, and then you can apply "low" or "high" using down or up on the controller to give you a wide variety of punches and kicks. There's a good set of combos and a fairly fluid system tucked away in here, as well as a solid blocking and countering system, and button mashing is punished frequently with the AI giving you a damn good spanking in the later stages, so it pays to learn the intricacies. In effect, this is IK+ put on steroids, and then given a serious training regimen, the Karate is pretty full featured (at least that an outside layperson can figure) and has a much more realistic, crunchy feel to it, as opposed to the more fantasy based fighters that you tend to run into.Training focusses on the various stats, or training you in new moves, the stat training can range from simple button mashing (for body conditioning, which will give you hand cramp, well, they did say it was toughness training - BEAR THE PAIN), to attempting to hit a tennis ball suspended by a piece of string, which feels a bit like the human version of a cat playing with a feather. Generally speaking some minigames work really well (the concrete bag, the strength tests, some of the toughness tests) and there's only a few real duds (the water droplet test can die in a fire). There's even a minigame where you work to build up funds to enter the starter tournaments, which... can go horribly wrong if you decide to fiddle about with your forklift (there's safety videos for that you know!).With all this said, would one recommend it? At the price point it's pitched at? Absolutely. It's a -steal-. There's a lot to do in this game, and it'll keep you busy easily for a good few evenings or a solid weekend, and you may well return to it every so often for a theraputic bit of Karate fighting in the later tournaments, even after you master the game. It's excellent value, and as a b-movie, modernised IK+, it's an easy sell. If you're into fighting games and fancy a change of pace, grab this and give it a whirl.

												Knock Down Blow is largely a martial arts sports game, sharing more in common with Budoken (1989) and the like than most other fighting games. It does not feature magic attacks, energy blasts, or even flips; but rather fists, feet, blood, sweat, tears, karate, forklifts and a bear. This provides for a more realistic, restrained, visceral and violent experience that defies the game’s appearance and feels quite unique to the genre.With liver injuries, skull fractures, brain damage and more all lovingly recreated, this game delivers a real sensation of beating the crap out of someone else, which will appeal to many Steam users. However, Karate Master also delivers a sensation of having the crap beat out of you, which many Steam users will relate to.Some of the training exercises depicted are tedious, some are momentarily fun. And while there is a cheese strategy or two for the actual fighting, timing and technique are rewarded and the results are most satisfying.

												OSU!In short; this game is a mixture of a classic arcade title like Karate Champs, IK+, or the obscure Chatan Yarakuu Shanku - The Karate Tournament, with Art of Fighting's visuals and the recent UFC titles' attention to detail, with a touch of RPG and simulation.If you look at the screenshots and expect Karate Master 2: Knock Down Blow to be a typical Street Fighter II clone straight from the 90s you'll be in for a surprise.  In this game you play as forklift truck driver and karate novice Ken during his young adult years in 1980s Japan as he hones his skills, tempers his body and soul, breaks his bones, and fights every rival in order to achieve his goal of becoming a karate master and open his own school.To accomplish this you will be tasked with taking on the various dojos of this harbour town, most of which are variations of karate, but you will also fight boxing, wrestling, Muay Thai, and Taikwondo practitioners, as well as the odd bull or car, and defeating their students to make a name for yourself.However, these dojos don't except a new face.  You need to earn fame by winning two types of tournaments, one with protective gear and one without.  The difference supposedly is face hitting is against the rules of the latter tournament, however there isn't any in game punishment for this so just go wild.  I did find it the tougher tournament of the two, but otherwise they're very similar.However, you will also need to earn money in order to enter these, and other tournaments, which is earned with a rather simple yet satisfying forklift minigame that brings back memories of the similarly themed Shenmue.Winning the tournaments and defeating dojos will earn you training days, which are used to increase your Stength, Speed, Toughness, Ki (stamina), and Tai Kitae (described as increasing the roughness of your skin, effectively it increases your chance of critical blows) which are handled via various mini games that are unlocked as you progress in each stat.  Unfortunately a lot of these are rather hit and miss, but they're short enough that they likely won't be too off putting, but you will be playing them a lot.As for the combat itself you have the d-pad and four face buttons, which for reference I will be using the X-Box pad layout for further descriptions.  Much like Tekken or UFC titles the face buttons represent Kens left and right punches and kicks, and the d-pad is used to aim for high, mid, or low strikes, combinations of the buttons are used for various techniques, and pressing the two punches together, plus a direction, will perform one of your defensive katas.Instead of a health metre, your body, as well as your opponent's, is represented by a small green silhouette which indicates damage to your head, legs, arms, or torso by changing to light green, yellow, orange, and finally red.  This increases the chance of being knocked out, but fortunately does recover slightly.  I'm not certain what governs recovery as such, but you'll sometimes be very grateful for a Yame, where the fight pauses due to either one of the combatants falling to te mat or going out of bounds, after which the combatants return to their starting positions.  This gives you a moment for recovery of both your health and Ki, though be warns, if you've taken too much of a beating you won't heal at all.Fights are tense at first, as a single strike can end a match due to the opponent being too strong, or them breaking your bones with a critical.  When this happens you end up in hospital and must engage in a mini game to heal.  Fortunately this action goes both ways, meaning you can score a luck strike as well.The game feels both technical and arcadey, I don't want to say I had to use a lot of skill beyond targeting a certain area, and some fights can feel like they're just a war of attrition, but at the same time are very enjoyable.  Hitting a heavy blow or dazing an opponent by getting in a Brainshock or similar feels great, and having to back off and rethink your game due to getting pulverised in the first few seconds and make a very tense moment or two, leading to a more brutal feel than the more famous fighters out there.The visuals and sound really help there, seeing a realistic amount of blood splattering the fighters and the floor, heay blows sounding like an explosion as the game momentarily shudders as the screen is framed with a red haze, and the aforementioned Brain/Livershock, being left breathless, or a receiving muscle injury causes a dizzying, wobbly effect as the fighter starts staggering as they try to fight, all of it leads to a real sense of risk and struggle.The graphics aren't superb sadly, the sprite work, while effective, does look very rough, especially on some of the fighters, and some of the backgrounds are poorly rendered polygon work, though it has some of the better audiences I've seen in a game.  The music is pretty good, if not very memorable.  It has the feel of an old Tokusatsu show, as well as a classic beat 'em up, and fits the game very well.Unfortunately the game does have some issues, occasionally the controls would become unresponsive, and the game can be rather repetitive, as grinding is necessary to max out your stats, and get enough money to get through the game.  It also hurts that there's a distinct lack of multiplayer, which would be great in a game this dedicated to an authentic feeling fighting game RPG.I spent around 6 hours in order to get to the credits, which considering the price is very good.  I can honestly say I had a huge amount of fun in that time, and would love to play more.  Hopefully there will be a sequel some day, with multiplayer included.

												Oh man what a fun little ride this was.I had no idea what I was geting when I picked this game up, but felt very intrigued by the bright colors and music of the trailer. Bears, cars and bulls? Boxers? Wrestlers? No way the game had all of this. But oh yes my friends, it certainly does.First off a big nod has to go to the presentation of this game. The graphics are large, detailed, very nice looking and overall just make the game very fun to watch. You definately get an old school SNES Final Fight/Street Fighter vibe from them. As well, all of the music is good, whether its the main menu or the bloody end of a fight, it fits and its damn good. Now the game was obviously translated from japanese and it isn't perfect, but this leads to some hilarious lines, one of my favorites being "I"ll break your idiot face, you sucker!" But it's like one of those badly dubbed japanese films, you can't help but smile at it.There is a story to the game, sort of. You can tell there is supposed to be large overall narrative but the actual story scenes are so few and far between you kind of just get some randomness. Basically your character wants to become a great karate master and open his own school. You do this by training, learning new moves, and beating the crap out of the other dojo leaders in the city and competing in tournaments. Along the way you get cutscenes asking you to do the crazy stuff like fighting bears and bulls, and all of this gets you more and more fame. The more famous you are the more dojo leaders you can confront and more tournaments you can earn until you get to the end of the game.But really, the gameplay is where it's at. Even after over ten hours there are still some nuances like proper counters, etc, that I didn't pick up on. For me it was mostly back away and then attack, but you might do better then I did. You essentially have two kick buttons, two punch buttons, and a jump. You also get what is called a Ki bar and if you let it fill before you attack you do more damage. Like some of the best wrestling games, you also have body damage, so you can do damage to legs, torso, or head, and by doing enough damage to one part you can knock your opponent out and win the match. Also at random you can end up losing your breath, taking damage to your liver or getting 'brain shock' which disables you a There is a fair bit of depth here and it's a shame the engine they came up with is single-player only as this would make an excellent competitive fighter.In terms of the progression, it oddly enough, has a difficulty drop rather then a spike. At first it is tricky, as you are weak, have to earn all of your money working as a dock worker via a mini-game, and fight in tournaments and probably lose. But whenever you lose you get some experience towards your skills. Eventually you'll win a tournament and be able to train up a bit more. Once you get some training under your belt and raise your stats a bit, you'll end up breezing through most of the tournaments and can start to challenge the dojos, which are FAR easier. You can actually challenge the same dojo over and over again, getting experience, and fame each time, along with training points to use towards upgrading your skills and learning new moves. As a tip, be sure to learn the new moves, or WAZA,  as soon as possible; they make the game easier and more interesting. I screwed up and I didn't learn them until near the end of the game. With these moves, and your upgraded stats, in some cases you might end up conquering the dojos in less then a minute. But some of the tournaments and special events hold enough of a challenge to keep you going. Plus, due to a feature called 'Ichegaki Hissatsu' there is always a chance for you to lose (or win) randomly, as one lucky strke can fracture a leg or even your skill and end the match immediately so you never feel totally invincible or unstoppable, and thus the game never quite hits the point of getting boring.Overall the game is extremely fun to play, holds a great challenge, along with providing some very funny to read dialogue at some points. I encourage you to go master your karate as this game is a knock out blow of a recommendation. And more thing, for those of you with Steam controllers, I've exported a controller configuration for you to use that works marveiously, so go get it once you have picked up this excellent game.

												CHECK OUT MORE REVIEWS AT https://ethnographix.squarespace.com/ In a world where rehashed fighters have become all too common, sometimes a turd in the punch bowl is just what the party needs most. Karate Master 2 Knock Down Blow is a martial arts sim/fighter with an emphasis on precision and coordinated attacks. The mechanics rely heavily on effective blocking, footwork, and precisely timed strikes that reflect the reality of competitive martial arts in that for every attack made, an opening for counter-attack is similarly created. The button-masher in me had his ♥♥♥ handed to him early in the game before realizing this was not your mama's typical fighter.Real life knowledge of your opponent's school of attack will also factor in i.e. Tae Kwon Do's emphasis on footwork and kicks differs greatly from American boxing's heavy punches and speedy footwork. Visually, KM2 resembles early Art of Fighting Neo-Geo hits with a close up view of the combatants that provides an isolated view of combat while eschewing any emphasis on overly detailed backgrounds. It's you and one other warrior face to face; that's it.  The sound effects, in juxtaposition to the realism placed on combat, are meaty and sonic-boomy in their slapping power while most attacks are chalked full of  whoosh  that will make you exhale deeply as a roundhouse kick misses your grill by mere inches. There is a distinct emphasis on training as well as a surface-level understanding of the various elements of real life Karate and those with a background in the actual martial arts will find themselves rather pleased by the integration of the rules & etiquette expected from combatants. These rules will vary and the degree of padding (or lack thereof) required adds an element of risk as bone-breaking attacks during more informal bouts can lead to a significant amount of time out of the dojo spent on the mend as you channel the ♥♥♥♥ out of your spirit animal. All in all, KM2's the kind of game you'll probably do a bender through in a day or two but, for the price, it's well worth the nostalgic beat 'em up feel along with solid mechanics and sweet training sequences in the rain while you look determined as a mother. 												Oh man, that nostalgia. The electronic music, the city map, the cheesy 80's kung fu movie plot, and sprites that look like they come straight out of an SNK game. And that was the entire purpose: to relive the glory days of 16-bit fighting games.Karate Master 2 does a great job of running you through the karate journey as you'd expect from pop culture. There's not much backstory - your character is a maverick karateka who works at the docks for money, fights in tournaments to gain fame, goes through harsh training, beats up other dojos, gets invite to the secret kumite tournament and dreams of opening a school. And surprisingly, through all the generic archetypes of martial arts films and games, it's still satisfying to play this one through.The fighting system is actually quite good. No flash combos or special moves; just the straighforward punches and kicks that you can expect from a real karate tournament. Fighting rewards getting into the right range and using the right attack for maximum effect. Hits don't necessarily cancel each other out - one can still connect a punch or a kick after being struck. Rapid button mashing reduces the power of attacks. Training strength and hardness allows you to randomly perform critical hits that can stun the opponent or bring an instantaneous end through broken bones. And the same can happen to you.The pacing feels right for a 80's fighting game and is executed well. The campaign does become grindy after a while as you have to earn fame and money to complete the story. After training up your stats, fights become too easy, only requiring several punches to end, and the story doesn't introduce more challenging tasks or complex events, making the replay value effectively zero. You'll be done with the game in a day or two.But it was worth it.

												I just paid $10 for 5 hours of gameplay.  It was worth every penny.  Well, it was worth most of the pennies.This is a game that is very approachable despite its lack of tutorial or even an opportunity to get your bearings.  It throws you right into the action with no explaination.  However, it's easy enough to figure out.  The first challenge is the bad translation.  I'm not sure how this game happened, but I'm pretty sure it's a japanese indie.  Level up your strenght and perform the ching chong toyota weeaboo dahg suup.  After the translation comes the glitches.  I've only had to close it and reopen it twice, but it froze several times.  Have patience, and this won't be a problem.  There's also some funny glitches.  Tournament brackets will sometimes claim you've been eliminated when you haven't, and then the two contestants next to you have both beat each other.  It works itself out on its own.  There's also the boxing ring, where you can knock each other out at the same time but have to wait ten seconds before you crumple over and fall.  The final flaw is the grinding.  You have to go to work as a forklift operator to get money to enter tournaments, at least until you unlock the matches that give you money when you win.  There's also training minigames, which are actually really fun at first.  As soon as you get tired of doing them, you can just stop and let your stats level up on their own.  The button mashing will hurt your thumbs, but it doesn't go without reward.  The fighting itself consists of high kicks, mid kicks, low kicks, high punches, mid punches, and specials,  You can't throw fireballs, but you can do roundhouse kicks and high flying nose kicks.  You unlock those by pressing the "waza" button in the training menu.  Don't bother with the frontflip kick, spinning backfist, axe kick (leg goes straight up), or anything but the roundhouse and the spinning jump kick.  The fighting is really visceral, and you know when you land a good hit.  The game rewards you for having the skill to properly land a blow.  Don't be afraid to hit the body or the leg.  The head isn't the only way to win.  Working your opponent's leg is actually very effective.  Out of the three targets, head is the best - but not by much.  Don't worry about the story, it's ♥♥♥♥ and it doesn't get in the way.  Just kick someone's face in.  Story can wait.  When doing a tournament in the early game, I had a very intense second round that involved a lot of leg sweeping and face kicking.  It ended in me and my opponent punching each other in the stomach as fast as we possibly could, and then he fell over.  The third round consisted of the match starting, me closing in, one boot to the head, and it fractured his cranium.  The game will seem easy after a while, until you unlock the secret tournament.  I won't tell you what that is.  Just be prepared and have fun.  You'll end this game feeling proud of yourself.  You might even want to go again.  Personally, I would absolutely love to see the potential this game holds fleshed out a bit more.  Not many games need sequels, but this one does.  I want to see what else this developement team can do.  I see a lot of creativity in these people.

												Karate Master 2 is a 2D single-player only fighting game well worth its price-tag, offering a roughly 6-8 hour SINGLE-PLAYER ONLY experience. For those wondering, it also offers controller and arcade stick support (for PC-compatible sticks).The in-game graphics and music are well-made and truly represent the developer's vision in giving the game a late 80's/early 90's feel. Characters all either reference 70's/80's/90's era martial arts movies and famous figures (Most of which being 'Mas' Oyama) and cutscene artwork is well-made, however the art style for character portraits can at times look slightly off. That being said, the dialogue (in English, at least) is hilariously inconsistent - Whether or not the developers intended to give the game that "B-grade action movie" dialogue - and is entertaining at many times, to say the least.The gameplay offers only a single-player story mode that plays as a 2D-fighter with RPG levelling mechanics, all of which are delivered through various minigames. These minigames range from timing to mashing, and while some may appear tedious at first they are easy to pick-up and never too jarring as the game allows you to reap the rewards from excelling at a certain mini-game over another, offering 4 options for each in-game stat.The core gameplay is entertaining though at times inconsistent. Using a standard LP, RP, LK, RK setup without any set combos or movelists, the player already has all the tools they need to win. Therefore apart from the statistics [mechanic], the player has to rely on movement, spacing, counter-attacks and timing to win their fights. FGC enthusiasts could say that the game is heavily-'footsie' based, if that means anything.The defensive system is where the game is most interesting: The player will always be guarding at the middle of three heights, and must hold up or down to shift this guard. In addition to this are parries, which may also be performed at three heights using both punch buttons. Unfortunately and having played KM1, I can say that it is much more difficult than its predecessor to predict/anticipate/read enemy movements, making parries heavily luck-based. Also available to the player are standard dashing mechanics and a ducking mechanic (which I find much better than attempting to parry or guard high attacks).The enemy AI also seems to be completely random in terms of attack patterns and damage, where an enemy fought at the beginning of the game, at later stages, can randomly and instantly throw a match-ending attack. This is another aspect of the core gameplay - "Ikken Hissatsu" or instant-kill moves: Rather than being as they would be in other 2D fighters such as Guilty Gear/Blazblue, the instant-kills can be any move in KM2, so long as your 'timing' is perfect.Instant kills are difficult to describe as the only explanation offered behind gaining one is that an average of the character's strength and damage stats must exceed the opponent's toughness. As none of these stats are given for opponents it genuinely does happen almost randomly, although timing a counter-attack at where the opponent isn't guarding tends to yield them more often.In closing, KM2 is neither a fighting-game player's dream nor will it keep you coming back for more for too long over its short length, however it will scratch an itch for martial arts [and obviously, Karate] enthusiasts that other fighting games might not.The game will not convert players who don't like fighters, however if you're looking for a solid, serious-yet-tongue-in-cheek action game that throws back to the days before Street Fighter 2, KM2KDB is a good place to be.

There's also training minigames, which are actually really fun at first.  As soon as you get tired of doing them, you can just stop and let your stats level up on their own.  The button mashing will hurt your thumbs, but it doesn't go without reward.  The fighting itself consists of high kicks, mid kicks, low kicks, high punches, mid punches, and specials,  You can't throw fireballs, but you can do roundhouse kicks and high flying nose kicks.  You unlock those by pressing the "waza" button in the training menu.  Don't bother with the frontflip kick, spinning backfist, axe kick (leg goes straight up), or anything but the roundhouse and the spinning jump kick.  The fighting is really visceral, and you know when you land a good hit.  The game rewards you for having the skill to properly land a blow.  Don't be afraid to hit the body or the leg.  The head isn't the only way to win.  Working your opponent's leg is actually very effective.  Out of the three targets, head is the best - but not by much.  Don't worry about the story, it's ♥♥♥♥ and it doesn't get in the way.  Just kick someone's face in.  Story can wait.  When doing a tournament in the early game, I had a very intense second round that involved a lot of leg sweeping and face kicking.  It ended in me and my opponent punching each other in the stomach as fast as we possibly could, and then he fell over.  The third round consisted of the match starting, me closing in, one boot to the head, and it fractured his cranium.  The game will seem easy after a while, until you unlock the secret tournament.  I won't tell you what that is.  Just be prepared and have fun.  You'll end this game feeling proud of yourself.  You might even want to go again.  Personally, I would absolutely love to see the potential this game holds fleshed out a bit more.  Not many games need sequels, but this one does.  I want to see what else this developement team can do.  I see a lot of creativity in these people.

The game is a good for picking up and playing but my biggest problem with it is that after a while the challenge wears off. The Karate Masters of each dojo don't feel like masters just punching bags with arms and legs. Granted they did give the wrestling school master grappling however I don't think the AI prioritizes the grappling as the wrestler. This is a game that looks like it has a lot of promise behind it but feels horribly limited. Plus I'm not sure who thought the word BEATED was actually a word but apparently it is. The game tries to have some kind of plot as you climb your way to the top but fizzles out eventually and wasn't even that interesting to begin with. Sure each fight has a risk of you getting your skull cracked or leg broken but after toughness level 7 it hardly happens. I can't really complain at getting the game 40% off but there's an SNES Taekwon-do game  you can download the ROM for that's a lot more replayable than this is. There are some challenging side missions like fighting a bull or a bear or jumping over a car but those are too few inbetween the copy paste dojos. Even the Muay Thai dojo just felt like you were fighting one of the earlier Karate dojos. That's really my main gripe is that the masters of each dojo could've been so much more. The Kumite which is the last unlockable tournament could've been much harder than what it was. The move system is relatively easy to follow even to someone like me who gets easily turned away from most fighting games since I can't remember the super autistic combos. Overall if you ignore the thin story line the game is at least solid enough to play. It's easy to get lost on some of the training sessions due to lack of instruction on them but after a bit of trial and error it'll come to you. 												Going into this game, I was pretty sure I'd like it, given the gameplay footage I'd seen.  I definitely am enjoying the ride so far, and I only hope that the issues get ironed out to make this game perfect.First, the things they got right.  Speaking as a former karateka myself, these guys really know their stuff.  Furthermore, while it may look like mashing will get you places, it's a lot more tactical than it appears, and lining up your shots, varying your angles of attack, and knowing when to risk the big fancy techniques will get you far.  The AI is good, providing a tough challenge without making it feel impossible.  The training minigames are interesting and while repetitive, the ways they simulate what they represent make a lot of sense.  The look and sound are perfect for this kind of game, and the translation is actually part of what makes it so charming.  I really hope they leave in at least one mention of STRENGHT.EDIT: After having fixed the gamepad support and added keyboard macros for multi-button presses, I recommend this game even more highly to anyone looking for a fun single-player fighter.  It may seem like a normal game, but it's a really...A SPECIAL GAME!
